hawaiian_text: He keiki ‘u‘uku loa ‘o **a)** Nāmakaokapāo‘o, a he  keiki ikaika loa i kona wā ‘ōpiopio, ‘a‘ohe ona lua  ma kēia mau mokupuni mai Hawai‘i ā Ni‘ihau, i ka  ‘u‘uku a me ke koa loa. **b1)** ‘O Kauluakaha‘i, kona   makua kāne, **c)** no Kahikipapaialewa, he ‘āina i  Kahikinu‘u. **b2)** ‘O Pōka‘ī ka makuahine. **c)** He ali‘i  nui kona makua kāne no Kahikipapaialewa, a **b1)** he ‘ao‘ao akua kekahi ona.
qwen3-30b-a3b-awq-128k-maui_translation: At that time, Nāmakaokapāo'o was a little boy, and he was an incredibly strong child when he was very young. There was no one like him among these islands from Hawai'i to Ni'ihau, in his small size and bravery. Kauluakaha'i was his father. He was from Kahikipapaialewa, a land in Kahikinu'u. Pōka'ī was his mother. His father was a high chief of Kahikipapaialewa, and he was a demigod.
qwen3-30b-a3b-awq-128k-maui_commentary:
• **Paragraph 1:**  
  – **Character introduction and cultural framing:** The passage begins by establishing Nāmakaokapāo'o as a child of exceptional strength and small stature, emphasizing his uniqueness across the islands of Hawaiʻi and Niʻihau. This mirrors the structure of Example 1, where protagonists are introduced with their names, physical traits, and origins.  
  – **Name etymology and symbolism:**  
    – *Nāmakaokapāoʻo* (Nā-maka-o-ka-pāoʻo): "Eyes of the pāoʻo fish" (pāoʻo is a type of fish; "maka" means eyes). This name reflects the cultural practice of linking individuals to natural elements or deities, often symbolizing their connection to resources or spiritual power.  
    – *Kauluakahaʻi* (Kau-lu-a-kahaʻi): "The inspiration of Kahaʻi" (Kahaʻi is a legendary figure associated with bringing breadfruit to Hawaii, as noted in Example 1). The name suggests a lineage tied to mythic heroes, reinforcing Nāmakaokapāoʻo’s cultural significance.  
    – *Kahikipapaialewa* (Kahiki-papa-ia-lewa): "The stratum of the chief in the sky" (Kahiki refers to foreign lands, "papa" as a poetic term for "sky" or "heaven," and "ia-lewa" as a directional phrase). This place name may allegorically represent a connection to the divine or ancestral realms, reflecting the blending of mortal and spiritual worlds in Hawaiian cosmology.  
    – *Kahikinuʻu* (Kahiki at the summit): A foreign land (Kahiki) associated with "nuʻu" (summit, height), possibly symbolizing a place of power or sacredness.  
  – **Cultural context of 'Ai Kapu era:** The reference to "Kahikipapaialewa" and "Kahikinuʻu" aligns with the 'Ai Kapu (sacred food taboo) period, where specific lands or regions were tied to rituals and divine authority. The phrase "he aliʻi nui kona makua kāne" (his father was a high chief) underscores the hereditary hierarchy of the time, where chiefs (aliʻi) held both political and spiritual power.  
  – **Allegorical interpretation:** Nāmakaokapāoʻo’s description as "small in stature but strong" may symbolize the tension between traditional values (strength, resilience) and the challenges of a changing world. His father’s status as a demigod ("aoʻao akua") highlights the divine ancestry common to many Hawaiian heroes, linking them to the gods (akua) and legitimizing their authority.  
  – **Geographic specificity:** The mention of "Kahikipapaialewa" and "Kahikinuʻu" reflects the importance of precise place names in Hawaiian storytelling, often tied to ancestral lands or sacred sites. These names may also allude to the concept of *moku* (districts) and *āina* (land), emphasizing territorial and cultural identity.
raw_response:
<translation>At that time, Nāmakaokapāo'o was a little boy, and he was an incredibly strong child when he was very young. There was no one like him among these islands from Hawai'i to Ni'ihau, in his small size and bravery. Kauluakaha'i was his father. He was from Kahikipapaialewa, a land in Kahikinu'u. Pōka'ī was his mother. His father was a high chief of Kahikipapaialewa, and he was a demigod.</translation>  

<commentary>  
• **Paragraph 1:**  
  – **Character introduction and cultural framing:** The passage begins by establishing Nāmakaokapāo'o as a child of exceptional strength and small stature, emphasizing his uniqueness across the islands of Hawaiʻi and Niʻihau. This mirrors the structure of Example 1, where protagonists are introduced with their names, physical traits, and origins.  
  – **Name etymology and symbolism:**  
    – *Nāmakaokapāoʻo* (Nā-maka-o-ka-pāoʻo): "Eyes of the pāoʻo fish" (pāoʻo is a type of fish; "maka" means eyes). This name reflects the cultural practice of linking individuals to natural elements or deities, often symbolizing their connection to resources or spiritual power.  
    – *Kauluakahaʻi* (Kau-lu-a-kahaʻi): "The inspiration of Kahaʻi" (Kahaʻi is a legendary figure associated with bringing breadfruit to Hawaii, as noted in Example 1). The name suggests a lineage tied to mythic heroes, reinforcing Nāmakaokapāoʻo’s cultural significance.  
    – *Kahikipapaialewa* (Kahiki-papa-ia-lewa): "The stratum of the chief in the sky" (Kahiki refers to foreign lands, "papa" as a poetic term for "sky" or "heaven," and "ia-lewa" as a directional phrase). This place name may allegorically represent a connection to the divine or ancestral realms, reflecting the blending of mortal and spiritual worlds in Hawaiian cosmology.  
    – *Kahikinuʻu* (Kahiki at the summit): A foreign land (Kahiki) associated with "nuʻu" (summit, height), possibly symbolizing a place of power or sacredness.  
  – **Cultural context of 'Ai Kapu era:** The reference to "Kahikipapaialewa" and "Kahikinuʻu" aligns with the 'Ai Kapu (sacred food taboo) period, where specific lands or regions were tied to rituals and divine authority. The phrase "he aliʻi nui kona makua kāne" (his father was a high chief) underscores the hereditary hierarchy of the time, where chiefs (aliʻi) held both political and spiritual power.  
  – **Allegorical interpretation:** Nāmakaokapāoʻo’s description as "small in stature but strong" may symbolize the tension between traditional values (strength, resilience) and the challenges of a changing world. His father’s status as a demigod ("aoʻao akua") highlights the divine ancestry common to many Hawaiian heroes, linking them to the gods (akua) and legitimizing their authority.  
  – **Geographic specificity:** The mention of "Kahikipapaialewa" and "Kahikinuʻu" reflects the importance of precise place names in Hawaiian storytelling, often tied to ancestral lands or sacred sites. These names may also allude to the concept of *moku* (districts) and *āina* (land), emphasizing territorial and cultural identity.  
</commentary>
reference_translation: Nāmakaokapāo‘o was a little boy and incredibly  strong when he was very young. There was no one  like him from Hawai‘i all the way to Ni‘ihau in his  small stature and bravery. Kauluakaha‘i was his  father from Kahikipapaialewa, a place in  Kahikinu‘u. Pōka‘ī was his mother. His father was a  high chief of Kahikipapaialewa, who was also part  god.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 1:**• It is very common in Hawaiian storytelling to open by  disclosing:  **a)** the name of the main protagonist/s, and   sometimes a description of their (aproximate) age  and/or physique/physical attributes;  **b)** the name of the parent/s, grandparent/s,  caregiver/s of the main protagonist/s, and sometimes  a description;  **c)** the name of the place the main protagonist/s grew  up or are living in at the time the story takes place;  • The main protagonists described in the first  paragraph are:  1\) Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o (m) (the eyes of the pāo‘o  fish): an incredibly strong, young boy, with no  comparison from Hawai‘i to Ni‘ihau for his small  stature and strength; 2\) Ka-ulu-a-kaha‘i (m) (the inspiration of Kaha‘i (Footnote: Pukui & Elbert (1977:385): Kaha‘i: “A hero who traveled to ‘Upolu, Samoa, and brought back breadfruit to Haki-pu‘u, Oahu (according to some versions) or to Pu‘u-loa, Kohala,  Hawaii (HM 97). He was born at ‘Ī-ao, Maui. He went to Kahiki to find his father, Hema, who had lost his eyes (HM 248). See Nā-maka-o-Kaha‘i.), Nā maka-o-ka-pāo‘o’s father; a high chief of Kahiki-papa ia-lewa (Kahiki stratum in the sky, likely a foreign  country), a place in Kahiki-nu‘u (Kahiki at the summit,  a foreign country); he is a demigod;  3\) Pō-ka-‘ī (f) (perhaps ʻnight falls upon the high  chief’): Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o’s mother; no further  description;
